text: Thing was, I didn't realize this until later, but the weird video in the background of the menu is actually a close-up of the nuclei of a Metroid.
author: ranchdressing

text: Greatest. Menu. Music. Ever. Druids? Flippin druids humming in the background during the menu? Yeah, this is about to be epic! Menu music is not supposed to sound this amazing, first time I heard this, goosebumps everywhere! Retro Studios hit the nail on the head with this theme that set the pace and the tone for every piece of music in Metroid Prime that followed. Perfect.

text: Has it really been 10 years since this came out already???  Unreal.  Time flies.  I still remember booting this game up for the first time.  The menu music chilled me to the core.  One of my all time favorite games.
author: SilverAxe13

text: The problem with Other M isn't that Nintendo is slipping, so much as it's that Nintendo never understood how Retro used newer, more innovative exploration elements to create a more atmospheric, interesting, rewarding, exploration-leading-to-discovery, grandiose title. I wouldn't blame corporate greed so much as Yoshio Sakamoto's lack of understanding towards his own series. (Not that corporate greed isn't prevelant. See also Mass Effect 3 and any Capcom release after RE4's GCN release)
author: High Brow Comedy

text: Sadly corporate greed such as EA and Activision set in to monetize the gaming industry making it stagnate. Nintendo is slipping, Other M has no soundtrack and was mediocre overall, what a black sheep of the Metroid franchise.

text: I'd be less interested in a Retro developed fourth Metroid Prime, and more interested in a Retro developed 2D Metroid. i really hope they revive the Metroid Prime series, i bought the trilogy recently, and i love the games, i remember when i bought metroid prime on a whim, just because i had played metroid and super metroid back int he day, i though, why not, its now one of my favorite gameing series ever,

author: electricmastro

text: I don't remember the last time I uploaded two tracks from the same game so closely together, but Metroid Prime launched exactly 10 years ago so I couldn't pass that up. It makes me realise how video games have been evolving very slowly, especially when you compare the 1992-2002 jump to the 2002-2012 one. I'd be willing to spend quite the sum for a Metroid Prime 4 on the Wii U made by Retro.
